title.narrative: Mid Term Evaluation of the Expanding Network and Coverage of Terrestrial Protected Areas in Mauritius project

description.narrative: Assisting institutions to better manage protected areas and cleaning invasive species
independent political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration
Objective: To expand, and ensure effective management of, the protected area network to safeguard threatened biodiversity
1. Coverage (ha) of the terrestrial formal protected area network of mainland Mauritius and the islets:

comment.narrative:
State protected areas
8,027ha
Private protected areas
0ha

State protected areas
11,700ha
Private protected areas
3,220ha

The status quo in terms of protected areas has been maintained.
State Protected areas = 8,328 ha
Private protected areas = 0 ha
For Bassin Blanc, acquisition under appeal in valuation tribunal is still not finalized.
The management plans for the Bras d'Eau National Park and Black River Gorges National Park have been submitted during this reporting period.Both document proposes the creation of buffer zones , these will be delineated in the mapping under the Protected Area Network Expansion Strategy. Yet, the whole process of declaring the land around the parks must be initiated by the Ministry of Housing and Lands which is the local authority to define the land uses.
Regarding Mountain and River Reserves which covers approximately 6500 ha of privately managed land , their status as protected areas is still unclear. The Protected Area Network Expansion Strategy , expected for September 2015, will provide the underpinnings for adding these reserves and other potential reserves such as the corridor of 4000 metres linking Le Morne to the Black River Gorges National Park, to the protected area networks.
Concerning the Native Terrestrial Biodiversity and National Parks Bill, which makes provision for proclamation of of private reserves, is expected to be presented to the parliament in October 2015.

description.narrative: 2. Total operational budget (including HR and capital budget) allocation (US$) for protected area management [Note added to clarify that this indicator refers to the annual budget]

comment.narrative: More than US$4.1m

Target can be considered as being achieved. The total budget for PA's as Government budget allocation 2014 is estimated to be $ 6.2 m for the Forestry services and $ 2.4 m ( include funds from PAN project, approximately $800,000) for the National Parks and Conservation services. Additional funds of ~ US $0.25 m from National Parks and conservation funds has been used for Protected Areas. Other financing mechanism are also now in place such a Maurice Ile Durable (MID) fund to the tune of~ US $ 0 .4 m, for Protected Areas management. Moreover funds from private companies Corporate Social Responsibility ( CSR) have also been allocated as follows: HSBC= US $ 25,000 IBL= US $ 2,500 , Lions clubs = US $ 8,500. Total budget amounts to US $9.25 m

description.narrative: 3. Financial sustainability score (%) for national systems of protected areas

comment.narrative: Baseline application of the of the Financial Sustainability Scorecard (2009) yielded a general score of 17%
Application of the of the Financial Sustainability Scorecard at project end is expected to yield a general score 30-40% [Target adjusted after conclusion of inception report]

Target achieved. Financial Scorecard has not been re-worked for this reporting period Initiatives undertaken in 2013 and 2014 to improve the financial score of the PAs are still ongoing . Private companies are still directly contributing to PAs management in terms of ecosystem restoration and IAS removal activities in the PAs. The lions club , a service group, is channeling CSR funds from private companies for IAS clearing and forest restoration activities. The Maurice Ile Durable has continued to fund PA management and Ecosystem restoration in newly identified areas. There will soon be another source of funds from the European Union. The Indian Ocean Commission (IOC) have called for proposal for local biodiversity project to the tune of US $ 36 000 to US $ 90 000 per project.Deadline for submission of Project is August 2015.

description.narrative: 4. Capacity development indicator score (%) for protected area system:

comment.narrative:
Systemic 50%
Institutional 56%
Individual 62%

Systemic 78%
Institutional 60%
Individual 75% [Target adjusted after conclusion of inception report]

The Scorecard has not been applied again. Hence, it is not possible to inform the indicator. The Capacity development indicator will be calculated after the training programme has been finalized. The score generated will serve as a baseline. The Capacity Development indicator will be generated a second time after training completed and the outcome will be measure against the baseline.
Concerning the training need analysis, the exercise is nearly completed and data analysis should start soon.
Otherwise , an ecological restoration workshop to share good eco-system restoration practice through the development of a practitioners' guide/manual , is planned for September/October 2015.
Regarding actual training carried out during this reporting period, there has been two training sessions in December 2014 on the use of GPS. Staff from the Forestry services , NPCS and Ministry of Housing and Lands attended the training.

description.narrative: 5a. METT (Management Effectiveness Tracking Tool) scores for different categories of formal protected areas on mainland Mauritius and the islets - Conservation Management Areas within the Black River Gorges National Park

Morne SÃ¨che 50.6% During the project preparation phase there was comprehensive application of the METT methodology across the entire PAN, with the exception of forest reserves. This note applies for all other sub-indicators under indicator 5.

The METT Scores have not been worked out for this reporting period.Cleared and restored areas have indeed expanded but will not have a major impact on the scores. Though the METT is to re-calculated at the end of the project, the scores will be calculated again in 2016 by the CTA and PMU . The latter will then update the METT on a regular basis and use this as a Monitoring and Evaluation tool.

description.narrative: 7. Ecological corridors and marine-terrestrial linkages incorporated into the PAN

comment.narrative: None
2 (1 in South; 1 in North)

Target not yet achieved but additional progress made towards. The international team of consultants, EcoAfrica, is actively working on Protected Areas Mapping with GIS data from Ministry of Housing and Lands and GeoTerra with resolution up to 50 cm. These Mappings will then serve to visualize the potential linkages and corridors.

description.narrative: 8. Number of rare and threatened plant species (of 231 with a known distribution) having at least 1 wild population represented in the PAN.

comment.narrative:

Extirpated in the wild 1

Vulnerable 62

Previously considered extinct 6
Extirpated in the wild 2
Critically endangered 70
Endangered 33

Target achieved . No change since last year. An update status should be produced by the end of 2015 as the Red list specialist group of Mauritius is updating the red list status for flora.

description.narrative: 9. Reach of the communications and awareness programme as follows: 9a) Percentage of those participating in experiential learning programmes instigated by the PAN who show enhanced knowledge 9b) Percentage of those participating in experiential learning programmes instigated by the PAN who show positive changes in behavior. [NOTE ON LOGFRAME REVISION 2014:] Indicator #9 has been revised as a result of the MTR. It was not being properly informed in previous reporting periods anyway. It was previously formulated as follows: â€œReach (estimated number of people) of the communications and awareness programmeâ€? The MTR recommended this changed. The response was: Reach indicator does not tell us anything about the take-up of messages. This indicator will be improved. It will be based upon surveys of target audiences and these groups will be surveyed for changes in their knowledge, attitudes and practices regarding general issues of biodiversity conservation in Mauritius and specific project protected area network objectives. Training indicators have been revised to be outcome-oriented.

comment.narrative:
In order to adequately assess the target, now as a % of those reached out by the project, tailored surveys will need to be applied. [NOTE ON LOGFRAME REVISION 2014:] The baseline for indicator #9 It was previously formulated as follows: â€œBroad-based communications (estimated number of audience receiving different media message) t.b.d.
Outreach programmes (number of people attending) t.b.d.
Experiential learning programmes (number of people attending) t.b.d.
Lobbying of key decision-makers (number of people and institutions) t.b.d.â€?

9a) : At least 80% of those participating in experiential learning programmes show enhanced knowledge and attitude 9b) At least 50% of those participating in experiential learning programmes show positive changes in behavior. [NOTE ON LOGFRAME REVISION 2014:] Target for indicator #9 It was previously formulated as follows: â€œBroad-based communications (estimated number of audience receiving different media message) approx. 100,000. Outreach programmes (number of people attending) approx. 500. Experiential learning programmes (number of people attending) approx. 500. Lobbying of key decision-makers (number of people and institutions) 10 of 4.â€?

Further progress have been made towards the target. Since the facebook page has been created in July 2014 , the number of likes has add up to 960 . The awareness campaign is still being implemented with future experiential events coming. A National art competition on the theme of world biodiversity was launched on the 8th May 2015 and all entries had to be submitted on the 18th May 2015. The PMU is going to do a thorough analysis of the exercise and its output to create a baseline.Results from future competition will be compared to the baseline to find out whether there has been changes.
In addition, a national survey will be undertaken at the close of the awareness programme to look at changes in knowledge and behaviour.

description.narrative: Outcome 2) A institutional framework strengthened
10. Number of strategic plans prepared for PA institutions that are linked to the MTEF

comment.narrative: 3 [Target adjusted after conclusion of inception report]

There has been tangible progress towards this target.The review of the Bras d'Eau National Park Management plan has been fully reviewed and will soon go for public consultation process. Review of the Bras D'Eau operational plan has been completed in June 2015 and comments have been communicated to the International Team of Consultants for amendments.
Regarding the Black River Gorges National Park9BRGNP) Management plan, a first draft was submitted on the 16th February 2015. An amended version together with the annual operation plan (AOP) was submitted in June 2015 after comments were communicated. The PMU is actually driving the review of the BRGNP AOP.
Concerning the strategic planning, there has been continuous consultation with FS and NPCS during the different EcoAfrica missions .The submission of the strategic planning should follow the PANES.

At the baseline: $2.1 million

Approaching the target. Income from other sources for this reporting period adds up to US $ 1,330,000.00. Out of it, US $ 930,000 represents income to the NPCS from non-governmental sources , US $ 400,000 comes from Maurice Ile Durable Fund and the rest is CSR funds. However , it must be notified that the available fund of $ 930,000 has not yet been used.

description.narrative: 12. Number of tourism concessions awarded [NOTE ON LOGFRAME REVION 2014] In the MTR, the baseline has been amended to 2 and the target amended to 3.

comment.narrative:
2
[was originally 0]

3
[was originally 1]

Target not yet achieved. There has been important progress towards it. A tourism working group has been set up in September 2014 under the impulse of the International Team of Consultants. The main objective of this platform is to discuss the creation of the nature based tourism association and to put a structure in place that will assist to obtain and manage concessions.

description.narrative: 13. Number of private landowners concluding stewardship agreements:

comment.narrative: Informal, non-binding, agreements 0 Formal, legally binding, agreements 0

Informal, non-binding, agreements more than 6
Formal, legally binding, agreements more than 2

Target not yet achieved. The international team of consultants has submitted a first discussion paper on Conservation stewardship in April 2015 for review and comments.
The Ministry has approved the 7 Memorandun of Understanding between the private forest owners for IAS clearing and forest restoration on private lands in September 2014, The first installment was paid in January 2015. The National steering committee on the 28th May 2015 has approved to the request to increase the number of MOUs as IAS clearing is more cost effective under this scheme.

For this reporting period, there has not been much improvement with respect to 2013 reporting.
14a) Short Training Course: There has been two training sessions on the use of GPS . 15 staff members from the forestry service, National Park and Conservation Services and Ministry of Housing and lands were trained.
14b) Approaching and reaching 3, when target is 5 Mentoring programme:29 Parks Rangers ,Assistant Park Rangers, Forest Enforcement and Conservation Officer
14c) Approaching and reaching 3, when target is 5 Train-the-trainers programme :16 Park Rangers and Assistant Park Rangers .
14d) IAS and ecosystem restoration skills development, 43 manual workers, 4 Park Rangers 12 Assistant Parks Rangers, 10 Forest Officers are regularly trained on IAS removal and native forest restoration.

description.narrative: Outcome 3. Operational know-how in place to contain threats
15. Number of protected areas with updated and approved management plans

comment.narrative: 3 or more

Approaching the target. Much progress has been achieved with the submission of Draft management plans for the Bras d'Eau National parks in 2014 and the Black River Gorges National Parks in February 2015. The Former will soon go for a 2 months public review while the amended BRGNP management plan has just been submitted. For RTREBS , the drafting of the management plan should be completed by the end of 2015.

description.narrative: 16. Extent of area (ha) under active IAS management and ecosystem restoration

comment.narrative: 60 ha
500 ha [Target adjusted after conclusion of inception report]

Progress: More than 70% of target achieved. The area under conservation management area with active IAS management and ecosystem restoration achieved during this reporting period has increased to 369.18 ha -- that is 73.8 % of the target has been achieved. Maintenance weeding has already been carried out in 67.25 ha of native forests.A total of 21105 seedlings have been planted to June 2015.

description.narrative: 17. Average cost (US$/ha) of IAS control and ecosystem restoration

comment.narrative:
17a) Initial clearing and first follow-up US$9,000
17b) Subsequent follow-ups US$1,000

17a) Initial clearing and first follow-up US$3,000
17b) Subsequent follow-ups US$700
[NOTE ON LOGFRAME REVISION - 2014:] Target had adjusted for the first sub-indicator after conclusion of inception report, but the MTR recommended it that this target should be revised upward again. It was $2,000 for Initial clearing and first follow-up; and $500 for subsequent follow-ups US$500

Target has been achieved for initial weeding (17a) and is still progressing on follow up maintenance with a cost currently at 850 USD per ha (17b).The cost cannot be further decreased due to inflation and higher cost of living.

description.narrative: Building the capacity of stakeholders to manage freshwater resources in an integrated manner

title.narrative: UNDP GEF AIO SIDS IWRM project document

description.narrative: Building the capacity of stakeholders to manage freshwater resources in an integrated manner
independent political entity
Environment - policy, planning and administration
Project Operations and Management (UNEP and UNDP and accountable)
To accelerate progress on WSSD targets and IWRM and WUE plans and water supply and sanitation MDGs for the protection and utilization of groundwater and surface water in the participating countries

Limited connection to sewerage system (typically 41%); currently system operating at 10% capacity None None
None None IWRM is entrenched in the broader work of national partners 6 SIDS countries develop IWRM plans, meeting MDG target 7a Subsets of the AIO SIDS show demonstrable progress in improving water use efficiency and access to safe drinking water and/or basin sanitation, thereby making progress on MDG targets 7b or 7c respectively (P) Specific improvements in water resources management at 6 national demonstration sites National inter-ministerial committees support IWRM processes in 6 SIDS by close of project Mechanisms in place to monitor freshwater resources in 6 SIDS by close of project

comment.narrative:
Limited or no application of IWRM principles or tools and processes at various levels within SIDS
Limited awareness of various stakeholdersâ€™ roles in IWRM
Little or no exchange of experience regarding IWRM and best practices amongst SIDS 2 AIO SIDS countries have national cross-sectoral IWRM committees at different levels of deveopment Limited or in some cases no freshwater resource monitoring systems in place in the 6 AIO SIDS

National partners have knowledge of IWRM concepts and their roles in implementing IWRM and participate in IWRM related networks National partners are incorporating IWRM concepts and tools into their work at various levels Successful project demonstrations are replicated through other means
6 AIO SIDS have established interministerial committees managing IWRM processes 6 AIO SIDS employing monitoring framework for freshwater resources and this information informs water management

IWRM demonstration projects are ongoing in all six countries with functional IWRM coordination committees at Basin level. Through the multi-stakeholder plat forms and participatory approach, the project has created platform for addressing water challenges and awareness raising, effectively raising awareness at national level on benefits of IWRM adoption. Following the demonstration project intervention, number of gaps have been identified and policy recommendations made.

description.narrative:
Protection of groundwater resources, stabilization of coastal terrains and promotion of productive activities at coastal areas through the integrated planning and management of wastewater collection, treatment and reuse demonstrated in Tarrafal in the Island of Santiago Outputs:
1.1.1: Improved wastewater management systems, resulting in more treated wastewater as a alternative water source and reduced untreated wastewater discharge to the ground
1.1.2: Increased treated wastewater used for irrigation, resulting in less groundwater abstraction and increased crop productivity by the communities
1.1.3: Awareness raised on water use efficiency for domestic use as well as tourism sector

Groundwater quality monitoring m3 of wastewater collected for treatment (or # of households connected to WWT system) m3 of treated wastewater used for irrigation # of farmers trained for the micro irrigation system with gender disaggregated data # of trees planted as a natural barrier against salinazation # of awareness raising campaigns conducted

comment.narrative: Limited connection to sewerage system (typically 41%); currently system operating at 10% capacity None None None None

Extended sewerage system to 80% of households; system operating at its 30% capacity Xxx (TBD during the inception phase) Xxx (TBD during the inception phase) Xxx (TBD during the inception phase) Xxx (TBD during the inception phase)

Technical design completed and recommendations available Selection of household connection has been completed and 580 household mapped for connection to main sewer-line. This is expected to increase volume of wastewater by 40%
A total of 1750 halophite plants were planted to mitigate seashore erosion and salinization Seven major targeted awareness campaigns have been held reaching out to over 750 people. This include two events during a national fair on Environment in 2014 and 2015 in which over 250 persons visited the project promotional stand. In February 2014, a 3-days participatory IWRM workshop was held, raising awareness among key national level senior officials (a total of 28 participants representing different departments in the water sector). From September to November 2014, awareness raising events on theme "water is life" were held in Tarraffal involving primary and secondary schools students and teachers. Over 200 students were involved and sensitized.

description.narrative:
Improved water source protection through IWRM Planning and management in Mutsamudu on the island of Anjouan
Outputs:
1.2.1: Water resource assessment and monitoring systems established
1.2.2: Water quality improved through solid waste management and water source protection
1.2.3: Reservoir protected from the effects of small-scale farming practices
1.2.4: Watershed management plan for Mutsamudu developed
1.2.5: Awareness raised on IWRM and catchment management and its contribution to MDGs and gender empowerment

Water resources assessed at identified monitoring points; Water resource monitoring operational Solid waste collection system established and operational Volume/weight solid waste collected Volume/area of monitoring point covered in solid waste Catchment management committee established Watershed management plan # of training and awareness raising campaigns, with gender dis-aggregated data, on water source protection from solid waste and agricultural practice

comment.narrative:
No water quality or quantity monitoring data collected No collection system; amount of solid waste in River Mutsamudu not monitored
No committee exists No plan exists; no data collection or analysis exists to provide basis for management plan No community engagement on solid waste pollution; little awareness observed

Regular water resources monitoring programme established # of households increased serviced by solid waste collection system 30% reduction in solid waste observed at the monitoring point upstream of water supply intake; Committee established with clear TORs and operational Consultation with landowners and catchment s/h completed; watershed surveys conducted; watershed zone map produced; management plan endorsed by stakeholders Clean up campaigns attended by communities; all farmers in the area around reservoirs trained in best farming practice to reduce pollution on reservoir

Water resource assessment initiated and draft reports available. Socioeconomic assessment and participatory mapping and zoning initiated and draft reports available. A watershed management plan is expected to be completed by September 2015.
Consultation on solid waste management is ongoing, scenarios for solid waste management have discussed. A monthly solid waste cleaning day has been agreed on. Additionally, through project mobilization, several solid waste collection campaigns were held involving the general public, schools and military. Over 50% of the population of Anjuaon has been sensitized through various channels including outreach activities, workshops, and media (local radio and press).
in April 2015, a tripartite partnership with the University of Comoros, the Directorate of Water and Energy and Directorate of Environment and Forest was established for water quality monitoring. Under the partnership, the laboratory of the University of Comoros has been upgraded for water quality monitoring. On the other-hand, the University is providing ongoing technical support in monitoring and training.
In March and April 2015, two training for small scales farmers was held to promote soil erosion control practices. Training included onsite demonstration of good practices in which 10 small scale farmers were involved.
Two workshops were held on the development of watershed management plans for Mutsamundu river basin, and implementation approach agreed on.

description.narrative:
Protection of the freshwater lens of Thoddoo Island from salinization and agro-chemical pollution, with improved drought season aquifer yields
Outputs:
1.3.1: Sustainable and innovative groundwater extraction system (infiltration gallery system) established and operational
1.3.2: Agricultural practices improved, reducing groundwater contamination
1.3.3: Sustainable groundwater extraction systems accepted nationally as relevant to island potable water supply and planned for replication nationally.
1.3.4: Groundwater quality monitoring system established and operational by gender balanced trained locals

Groundwater quality baseline established # of plots receiving water supply from the infiltration gallery system with metering Reduced groundwater salinity(%) and electrical conductivity Reduced nitrates and phosphates in GW Groundwater quality monitoring system established

comment.narrative: Limited baseline water quality data No water provided from the system, All groundwater extracted from individual wells, no metering. Currently elevated salinity and electrical conductivity Limited data available on GW quality Non existent

50% wells on faming plots and 50% of household wells monitored 50% of agricultural plots on the island irrigated from the gallery System Salinity level below 700 µS/cm, 30% reduction from average baseline salinity level 30% reduction from the baseline data Gender balanced training given to farmers; 20 shallow boreholes established for GW quality monitoring

An integrated water supply plan was completed and technical design prepared and approved. 100% (about 2000) population of the Island will have have portable water supply. Bidding was completed and contractor hired. Works was commissioned by the Minister in May 2015 Water planning Committee for the Island was established, and actively involved in planning. The committee involves the Island Authorities, technical departments such as agriculture and fisheries as well as education and community representatives.

description.narrative:
The protection and sustainable utilization of the Northern Aquifer of Mauritius demonstrated through the integrated planning and management of wastewater collection, treatment and reuse
Outputs
1.4.1: Water Resources Assessment conducted to determine and monitor the safe yield and water quality of the aquifer
1.4.2: Improved water quality protection of the groundwater and lagoon water quality through improved wastewater treatment and management systems
1.4.3. Reduced stress on the aquifer through improved water demand management and dissemination of best practices, aiming for replication at the national level and beyond
1.4.4. Capacity strengthened and awareness raised among government, private sector and civil society for aquifer protection against over-extraction and contamination with special focus on climate change and gender empowerment

Water Quality Baseline developed: Vulnerability of the aquifer against pollution and extraction assessed
Increased m3 of treated wastewater reused as alternative water resources (for recharge, irrigation, etc.)
(co-fin) Impact assessment of the effectiveness of groundwater recharge using the treated wastewater against saline intrusion. Best practices for water demand management captured and disseminated to % of stakeholder bodies; # of briefings produced by % of stakeholders on water resource management and climate change/gender empowerment

comment.narrative: Limited hydrogeological data on the northern Aquifer 1500m3 per day injected in boreholes Effectiveness of the current practice unknown Limited awareness of policy makers about the importance to protect groundwater and lagoon; Limited awareness about saving water and polluting activities

As regards Output 1.4.1: Water Resources Assessment conducted to determine and monitor the safe yield and water quality of the aquifer - a consultant was appointed and specifications prepared for the drilling of 4-5 boreholes and installation of piezometers. Output 1.4.2: Improved water quality protection of the groundwater and lagoon water quality through improved wastewater treatment and management systems - The Wastewater Treatment Plant at Grand Baie has been operating and at the same time the consultancy services for the detail design for house connections has been awarded. It is expected that the house connections will be started in 2016. 1.4.3. Reduced stress on the aquifer through improved water demand management and dissemination of best practices, aiming for replication at the national level and beyond - A school competition was launched in May 2015 to raise awareness on water management and enhance the understanding of IWRM in the population. 1.4.4. Capacity strengthened and awareness raised among government, private sector and civil society for aquifer protection against over-extraction and contamination with special focus on climate change and gender empowerment - This will take place after the results from the drilling and water samples are analyzed.

description.narrative:
Integrated River basin management plan for the Rio Provaz Basin developed to enable equitable water resources allocation and protection, contributing to sustainable economic development, public health and environmental protection.
Outputs:
1.5.1: Quality and quantity of water Resources in the Rio Provaz basin assessed
1.5.2: Institutional capacity (cross-sectoral coordination) strengthened and decentralized (municipal) water management fostered through the development and implementation of Basin Water Resources Allocation and Protection Strategy
1.5.3: Water pollution reduced through improved wastewater treatment systems (piloting ECOSAN wastewater management), solid waste collection and disposal and residential sanitation at the poor communities.
1.5.4: Awareness raised of IWRM at the basin level to strengthen community participation in IWRM and to ensure sustainability

Area surveyed and reported Water resources level, flow and quality data; GW resources potential established Basin water management committee; Basin Water Resources Allocation and Protection Strategy # of households using Ecosan

comment.narrative: No formal inventories of land or water resources or use exists No regular data collection or quality assurance No stakeholder consultations on water resources management to date; no catchment management committee: no water resources management strategies at basin level or national level No Ecosan technology currently used

100% of catchments area surveyed Robust quantity and quality data sets collected; all major risk type assessed for GW extraction Stakeholders identified; Gender integrated catchment management committees established and operational; water resources management strategy developed in a participatory manner and endorsed by the basin stakeholders; the process at the demo basin informs the national level IWRM process 100% of constructed Ecosan units still in use at the end of the project (# of units TBD during the inception phase); lessons learned produced aiming for further promotion

Water Resource Assessment and mapping of Rio Provaz Basin was undertaken. 100% of the basin has been surveyed and mapped and draft reported submitted. Water resource status has been simulated from limited data available. Basin coordination committee established; at list 5 meeting held; committee members are trained on 7 relevant aspects. On solid waste, a large amount of solid waste has been cleared, and this continues with an estimated solid waste collection at 20 m3 per month. Several awareness campaigns have been carried out to raise awareness on river basin protection, at least 50% of the population has been reached. A specialized firm to support on Eco-sanitation promotion, training and construction has been recruited. Work is scheduled to start thereafter.

description.narrative:
Protection of a coastal gravel aquifer through integrated land and water management measures (water demand management, land use, flood management) demonstrated in the island of La Digue
Outputs:
1.6.1: Water abstraction reduced through water demand management measures, including rainwater harvesting, household water tanks to reduce peak water demand, wastewater reuse, improved metering and tariff reform
1.6.2: Groundwater availability and quality improved through improved septic tank management, wastewater collection and treatment, prevention of seawater intrusion, solid waste collection, and groundwater recharge.

# of households business and community buildings with rainwater storage tanks m3 of re-used effluent % reduction in peak water pressure requirements through installation of # of household water storage tanks % reduction in leakage in water supply distribution system Surface water salinity in marsh outlets and GW salinity; aquifer recharge capacity of marshland restored Volume of waste oils and batteries collected

comment.narrative:
Rainwater harvesting practiced only marginally
No wastewater reuse practiced Limited # of households with potable water storage tanks No leakage detection and reduction programme; bulk metering only at water treatment plant; Inflow of seawater at high tide conditions; no tidal flaps installed; development pressure reduced natural buffering capacity of marshland Existing collection programmes not effective no collection

100% of targeted buildings using rainwater at domestic and commercial levels
Landscape irrigation schemes using treated wastewater at two hotels
Mandatory installation of potable water storage tanks for all new buildings 10% reduction in system peak pressures District meters installed and monitored; # of leaks fixed; #m of damaged pipes replaced #% reduction of m3 of water loss (#s TBD during the inception) 4 tidal flaps installed; no seawater flows inland into marshes; reinstatement of the marshland 70% of households using collection system

Rainwater harvesting promoted, 55 house holds adopted rainwater harvesting (with storage tanks at subsidized rates).
Consultancy on technical design and cost-benefit analysis of waste water treatment was undertaken. Hotels were involved and sensitized on the benefits of adoption of the water treatment.
Study on the solid waste disposal was completed and part of the recommendations on improvements taken up during the reporting period. Through collaboration with the Landscape and Solid Waste Management authority, a task was completed on collection of all batteries in the Island. Project also supported the regular solid waste collection through provision of more bins for solid waste collection. Several awareness campaigns were held during major national and international water and environment events involving the general public and schools

description.narrative:
Project implemented effectively and efficiently to the satisfaction of partners
Outputs:
5.1.1 Capable human resources and efficient systems support project implementation
5.1.2 Monitoring, consultation and advisory mechanisms support project implementation
Project systems work efficiently to provide high quality technical support to countries in IWRM reforms and demonstrations

comment.narrative: No project,
Effectively and efficiently implemented project

The Results and Knowledge Management Specialist (as part of the Regional Coordination Unit) undertook monitoring and support visit to all the countries during the reporting period. During the visit, project progress and challenges were discussed and recommendation made. The Regional Coordination Unit organized a Regional Workshop for all the National Focal Points and the Demonstration Project Manager. The UNDP RTA and UNEP Task Manager participated in the workshop. The workshop provided unique opportunity for networking, monitoring on progress as well as
backstopping.
In addition to the regular backstopping by the RTA, the visit to Seychelles Demonstration project was undertaken in June 2015 by the UNDP RTA.
